natural problem:
An integer $X$ has the following properties:

1.) $X$ is a multiple of 17

2.) $X$ is less than 1000

3.) $X$ is one less than a multiple of 8.

What is the largest possible value of $X$?
natural solution: Let the desired number be $a$. Then \begin{align} a \equiv 0 & \pmod {17}\\ a \equiv -1\equiv 7 & \pmod 8 \end{align} The first congruence implies that there exists a non-negative integer $n$ such that $a=17n$.

Substituting this into the second congruence yields $$17n\equiv 7\pmod 8,$$ $$\implies n\equiv 7\pmod 8.$$ So $n$ has a lower bound of $7$. Then $$n\ge 7,$$ $$\implies a=17n\ge 119.$$ $119$ satisfies both congruences, so subtracting it from both sides of both congruences gives \begin{align}

a-119\equiv -119\equiv 0 &\pmod {17}\nonumber\\ a-119\equiv -112\equiv 0 &\pmod 8\nonumber \end{align} Since $\gcd(17,8)=1$, we get $a-119\equiv 0\pmod{17\cdot 8}.$ That is, $a\equiv 119\pmod {136}.$ Note that every number that satisfies this congruence satisfies the original two congruences.
The largest number of the form $119+136m$ for some non-negative integer $m$, and less than $1000$, is $119+136\cdot 6=\boxed{935}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes X :: int
assumes h0 : "X mod 17 = 0"
and h1 : "X < 1000"
and h2 : "(X + 1) mod 8 = 0"
shows  "X = 935"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An integer $X$ has the following properties:

1.) $X$ is a multiple of 17

2.) $X$ is less than 1000

3.) $X$ is one less than a multiple of 8.

What is the largest possible value of $X$? The final Answer is 935
 ### Proof
 Let the desired number be $a$. Then \begin{align} a \equiv 0 & \pmod {17}\\ a \equiv -1\equiv 7 & \pmod 8 \end{align} The first congruence implies that there exists a non-negative integer $n$ such that $a=17n$.
 Substituting this into the second congruence yields $$17n\equiv 7\pmod 8,$$ $$\implies n\equiv 7\pmod 8.$$ So $n$ has a lower bound of $7$. Then $$n\ge 7,$$ $$\implies a=17n\ge 119.$$ $119$ satisfies both congruences, so subtracting it from both sides of both congruences gives \begin{align}
 a-119\equiv -119\equiv 0 &\pmod {17}\nonumber\\ a-119\equiv -112\equiv 0 &\pmod 8\nonumber \end{align} Since $\gcd(17,8)=1$, we get $a-119\equiv 0\pmod{17\cdot 8}.$ That is, $a\equiv 119\pmod {136}.$ Note that every number that satisfies this congruence satisfies the original two congruences.
 The largest number of the form $119+136m$ for some non-negative integer $m$, and less than $1000$, is $119+136\cdot 6=\boxed{935}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes X :: int
assumes h0 : "X mod 17 = 0"
and h1 : "X < 1000"
and h2 : "(X + 1) mod 8 = 0"
shows  "X = 935"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find an integer $X$ less than 1000 that is divisible by both 17 and 8 (when 1 is added to it). The final answer is 935.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes X :: int
assumes h0 : "X mod 17 = 0"
and h1 : "X < 1000"
and h2 : "(X + 1) mod 8 = 0"
shows  "Max {X. X mod 17 = 0 \<and> X < 1000 \<and> (X + 1) mod 8 = 0} = 935"
a_4.formal solution:

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "x mod 17 = 0"
and h1 : "x < 1000"
and h2 : "(x + 1) mod 8 = 0"
shows  "Max {x. x mod 17 = 0 \<and> x < 1000 \<and> (x + 1) mod 8 = 0} = 935"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An integer $X$ has the following properties:

1.) $X$ is a multiple of 17

2.) $X$ is less than 1000

3.) $X$ is one less than a multiple of 8.

What is the largest possible value of $X$? The final Answer is 935
 ### Proof
 Let the desired number be $a$. Then \begin{align} a \equiv 0 & \pmod {17}\\ a \equiv -1\equiv 7 & \pmod 8 \end{align} The first congruence implies that there exists a non-negative integer $n$ such that $a=17n$.
 Substituting this into the second congruence yields $$17n\equiv 7\pmod 8,$$ $$\implies n\equiv 7\pmod 8.$$ So $n$ has a lower bound of $7$. Then $$n\ge 7,$$ $$\implies a=17n\ge 119.$$ $119$ satisfies both congruences, so subtracting it from both sides of both congruences gives \begin{align}
 a-119\equiv -119\equiv 0 &\pmod {17}\nonumber\\ a-119\equiv -112\equiv 0 &\pmod 8\nonumber \end{align} Since $\gcd(17,8)=1$, we get $a-119\equiv 0\pmod{17\cdot 8}.$ That is, $a\equiv 119\pmod {136}.$ Note that every number that satisfies this congruence satisfies the original two congruences.
 The largest number of the form $119+136m$ for some non-negative integer $m$, and less than $1000$, is $119+136\cdot 6=\boxed{935}.$
 *)

fixes x :: int

and h2 : "(x + 1) mod 8 = 0"
shows  "Max {x. x mod 17 = 0 \<and> x < 1000 \<and> (x + 1) mod 8 = 0} = 935"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
